Hey Clara, have a question. So my idea is to make this scripts slash binary actually control a folder which it doesn't belong to. to solve the idea is. You see that we perform operations on the dots folder. The thing is, this repository will be inside of a folder in dot configurations that is not dots. It's so purpose is to manage dots, but it is not part of dots, because the idea is dots is supposed to be the repository where your dot files live, but not the repository where the binary that controls it lives. 

Two Separate Repositories:
1. Tool Repo (e.g., ireallylovemydots or ilovemydots)

Contains: dots binary + install.sh script
Purpose: Distributed/installed ONCE
Users interact with it during installation only

2. Dotfiles Repo (user's own - github.com/username/dotfiles)

Contains: Actual config files in config/ and home/ folders
Lives at: ~/.config/dots/ on user's machine
Separate git repo that the tool manipulates
Each user has their own

1.content:
cmd_setup() {
    local repo_arg="$1"
    [[ -z "$repo_arg" ]] && error "Usage: dots setup <username/repo> or <full-git-url>"
    
    check_dotfiles_repo
    cd "$DOTFILES"
    
    # Check if remote already exists
    if git remote get-url origin >/dev/null 2>&1; then
        local current_remote=$(git remote get-url origin)
        error "Remote already configured: $current_remote\nTo change it, run: cd ~/.config/dots && git remote set-url origin <new-url>"
    fi
    
    # Convert shorthand to full URL if needed
    local git_url
    if [[ "$repo_arg" == *"github.com"* ]] || [[ "$repo_arg" == "git@"* ]]; then
        # Already a full URL
        git_url="$repo_arg"
    else
        # Assume GitHub shorthand (username/repo)
        git_url="https://github.com/${repo_arg}.git"
    fi
    
    # Add remote
    git remote add origin "$git_url"
    
    success "Connected to $git_url"
    info "Now you can run 'dots sync' to push/pull"
}
